Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Synthesis and Structure-Property Elucidation of Direct-Bandgap Group IV Alloy Nanocrystals for Optoelectronic Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: The production of high-efficiency optoelectronic materials based solely on low-cost, non-toxic, and abundant Group IV elements such as silicon is challenging as Group IV elements are less efficient in electron-photon conversion process compared to the widely used optoelectronic materials. This project utilizes the unique nanoscale size confinement effects and alloying with tin to produce silicon-tin, germanium-tin, and silicon-germanium-tin nanocrystals that exhibit superior light absorption and emission properties. The collaborative team supports the synthetic efforts along with advanced optical characterization and theoretical calculations to garner a deep understanding of the emerging materials properties and enhance the optoelectronic performance. The interdisciplinary research provides valuable training to the graduate and undergraduate students in the areas from smart material design to device testing. Other education and outreach activities include K-12 nanoscience outreach efforts and involving the under-represented high school students and women in summer research activities.

Technical Description: Group IV semiconductor-based alloys with a direct bandgap are a long-sought goal in the field of optoelectronic materials. However this effort has been hindered primarily by the challenges in material design and synthesis, as well as the limited solubility of Sn in Si and Ge. This project utilizes both the quantum confinement effect and the Sn nano-alloying approach to produce direct bandgap Group IV alloys in nanocrystal form. The nanocrystals exhibit size and composition tunability that leads to wider effective bandgaps and superior photophysical properties. For example, GeSn, SiSn, and GeSiSn alloy nanocrystals with well controlled morphology and composition, far beyond the miscibility limit of Sn in bulk Si or Ge, are achieved via an innovative high-temperature colloidal synthesis method. Sn composition and quantum confinement effects on the indirect-to-direct bandgap transition are systematically investigated using steady-state and ultrafast absorption and emission spectroscopy, guided by computational simulations. The electronic structure calculations are used to establish a fundamental understanding of confinement-induced quasi direct bandgap behavior, composition-induced transition to true direct-gap, and surface/defect related effects on photophysical properties. Selected alloy nanocrystals linked by molecular metal chalcogenides are deposited on various substrates using low-cost, solution-based processing methods to demonstrate their potential for optoelectronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this program is to develop wet-chemical routes for direct energy gap germanium-tin (Ge1-xSnx) alloy quantum dots (QDs) displaying control over morphology and composition; investigate their physical properties as a function of QD size and alloy composition; and probe their carrier dynamics (electron and hole recombination) using steady-state and time-resolved optical spectroscopy supported by theoretical electronic structure calculations.  Over the past ~4 years, we have reported the wet-chemical synthesis of Ge1-xSnx alloy QDs with varying sizes (1.8−2.2 nm, 3−5 nm, 4−6 nm, and 15−20 nm) and Sn compositions (0−28%) displaying both size- and composition-tunable direct energy-gaps across visible to near infrared spectrum.  Synthetic handles (reaction temperature, growth time, concentration of precursors and surfactants) that govern the size, shape, and composition of alloy QDs were thoroughly investigated and reported.  The effects of quantum-confinement and Sn nano-alloying on indirect-to-direct electronic structure transition, absorption energy tunability, photoluminescence (PL) efficiency, carrier (electron and hole) lifetimes, surface/core recombination phenomena, and mechanisms of PL were probed by steady-state and ultrafast spectroscopy, supported by theoretical calculations.  The carrier dynamics of direct-gap Ge1-xSnx alloy QDs indicate slow decay (3−27 μs) of PL at 15 K, due to slow recombination of dark excitons and carriers trapped at surface, and at least one order of magnitude faster recombination with increasing Sn concentration to X = 0.236.  Increasing temperature to 295 K resulted in ~three orders of magnitude faster PL decay (9−28 ns) owing to the activation of bright excitons and carrier de-trapping from surface.  A possible mechanism for the origin of PL has been proposed based on detailed carrier dynamics studies supported by theoretical calculations.  The ultra-small (1.8−2.2 nm) alloy QDs show enormous quantum confinement effects and composition-tunable direct energy-gaps in the visible spectrum (2.16−1.55 eV for 1.8−23.6% Sn compositions).  In contrast, the intermediate size (3−5 and 4−6 nm) alloy QDs exhibit composition-tunable energy gaps in the near IR spectrum (1.72−0.84 eV for 1.5−20.6% Sn compositions) and an indirect-to-direct electronic structure transition at ~5.5−6.7% Sn composition.  The energy gaps of Ge1-xSnx alloy QDs are significantly larger than those reported for bulk Ge1-xSnx alloy thin films (0.73−0.32 eV for 1.8−14% Sn compositions), consistent with the expected quantum confinement effects.  Moreover, as-synthesized alloy QDs exhibit high thermal stability and moderate resistance against sintering up to 500 oC.  This enormous stability of gray-Sn in cubic germanium, has not been reported previously, and is highly advantageous for fabrication of QD thin films for future electronic and photonic studies.

In addition to experiments, theoretical (Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE) hybrid functional) calculations were used to garner an in-depth understanding of QD physical properties.  We showed that the hybrid functional theory, tuned to yield experimental band structure of bulk germanium, can be used to reproduce experimentally measured properties of Ge1-xSnx alloy QDs such as lattice constants, energy gaps, and absorption and PL spectra in good agreement with experiments.  The HSE calculations were also used to analyze the nature of the dark excitonic states in 1−3 nm QDs and dark-bright exciton splitting energy as a function of alloy composition.  As such, combined synthetic efforts along with advanced optical characterization and theoretical calculations provided an in-depth understanding of the emerging physical properties of this exciting QD system.  In summary, this program addressed the major bottleneck (indirect-gap) for efficient use of germanium in optoelectronics, expanded the optical window of direct-gap, silicon-compatible Ge1-xSnx alloys into technologically indispensable visible to near IR spectrum, and empowered their application in a number of new electronic and photonic studies.  The colloidal synthesis developed allows for solution-phase fabrication of alloy thin films, which is incredibly cost effective than traditional molecular beam epitaxy and chemical vapor deposition methods.

To date, twenty-four students (thirteen graduate, seven undergraduate, three high school students and one high school teacher) were involved, at least in part, with this research.  This program thus far resulted in one patent application, eight publications, three doctoral dissertations, and three master's theses.  In addition, three undergraduate students completed honors thesis projects.  All doctoral and master's students have achieved industrial and academic positions.  All former undergraduate researchers from this project are completing advanced degrees.  Fourteen presentations were delivered by students at national ACS and MRS meetings.  Fifteen invited seminars were presented by PIs at colleges and universities.  Minority high school students and teachers were trained on the synthesis of silicon and germanium QDs and their physical characterization via absorption and PL spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).  They presented research products (photoluminescent Si QDs) to a group of high school students from Richmond Public Schools (90% minority), impacting ~100 students.  Many students were unaware about research opportunities until these demonstrations.  All these efforts contributed to broader educational experience beyond their traditional expertise (i.e. Chemistry, Physics, and Engineering) for all students involved with this program.
